page.title: 15GREAT WEST PLANTATION STUDY
page.content: The above woodland is near Upsall Hall. At approximately 46.7m above sea level, under the shade of the coniferous trees, little grew in the way of plants. Under a simple everyday plastic bag, we found small and large snails, woodlice and other insects. Between the trees there was very little sunlight, but where there was, brambles and blue-bells took over. Lower down the hill at approximately 32.9m above sea level there were Oaks, Beeches, Elderberry, Sycamores, Silver Birches and other types like Holly and Common Ash growing in the deciduous part of the wood. The land we covered was l94m running East to West. The girth measurements of the trees were from 50 to 285cm. We also found 3 pheasant chicks which were so well camouflaged we nearly stood on them.
